column1: The number of columns of data in a file can vary from line to line and each line would be linked to a corresponding line in another file through a shared ID. This set up closely matches a database with primary and foreign keys except that not all tables have primary keys as we don't expect to be rewriting this data. So, in effect, each file is a separate database table. Data from only two sheets were extracted; '2. Emission Units & Activities' and '3. Material Balance.'

company source number, Hash with key|values "addr"=>[file_name, company_name, st address, city address, zip], "emi" => [true/false data present in sheet 2. Emission Units, CAS formula if any], "mat" => (same as emi but for sheet 3. Material balance)
the columns present depend on the particular sheet that the company submitted (this is variable and headers are found in corresponding entry in 2016_units.txt using the units_ID)
row_ID, 1st aggregate data column, 2nd aggregate data column, ..., units_ID
the columns present depend on the particular sheet that the company submitted (this is variable and headers are found in corresponding entry in 2016_units.txt using the units_ID)
row_ID, 1st descriptor column, 2nd descriptor column, ..., units_ID

The columns in this file include all columns associated with a particular chemical (either associated with a CAS number or occaisionally, no CAS number was provided but a grouping description was used). In most instances, there are three columns for a particular entry (line) and others there is just one (% weight). So, there is no link (foreign key) to the 2016_units.txt. The first column is row_ID and the second column is the Excel column header (eg 'A').
row_ID, row number on sheet, sheet_key ("emi | mat"), company source number, file name
This file holds column headers for the columns associated with both sheets
units_ID, [all column headers up to but not including CAS columns held in an array], number for last descriptor column

For example a 3 present in this last column would indicate that for this sheet columns 1 - 3 are descriptors [data found in 2016_[emi | mat]_desc.txt] and remaining columns are headers for aggregate data [data found in 2016_[emi | mat]_agg.txt]. The same outcome can be obtained by looking at the number of columns in a row of 2016_[emi | mat]_desc.txt and knowing that the first columns in the corresponding units row in 2016_units.txt would apply, while the remaining columns would apply to the corresponding 2016_[emi | mat]_agg.txt.
